Every American has the right to breathe clean, unpolluted air.

For the last five decades, the Clean Air Act has helped us protect that right and deliver cleaner air for all Americans—but we're not done. We must keep working to ensure the next generation can enjoy this right.

Today, 132 years ago, members of the Lakota Tribe were horrifically massacred at the hands of the United States government at Wounded Knee. 

That moment in our nation’s history can never be taken back, but it falls on all of us to never let up our work to right this wrong.

Merry Christmas! Wishing joy, love and holiday cheer to all.🎄

Yep, you're reading this right. The same Republicans who claim to “defend family values” just blocked my bill to protect the right to start a family through IVF.

And yes, it's the ultimate, nightmarish blend of hypocrisy and misogyny that you think it is.

Without the miracle of IVF, my two beautiful girls might not exist.

Tonight, I’m urging my colleagues to pass my Right to Build Families Act so we can protect IVF and every American’s right to choose how they build their own family. https://t.co/HR6GfaHPGJ

Let's be clear: they're coming for our right to access IVF next.

Soon, I'm going to the floor to ask for unanimous consent to protect IVF by passing my Right to Build Families Act.

If Republicans truly cared about being "pro-life," they wouldn't try to stop us from creating it.

The expanded Child Tax Credit in the Democrats' American Rescue Plan was a lifeline to so many families—including the families of our servicemembers and Veterans. 
 
We must bring it back.

Absolutely tragic. My heart goes out to these kids’ families and loved ones, and to the entire Juarez HS community. Tonight, I am more convinced than ever that while we’ve made important progress Congress, we must do more to end senseless and preventable gun violence like this.

Today I visited one of @fly2ohare new @MAMAVA pods, thinking of nursing parents who have to figure out how to feed their hungry baby in a busy airport. I’ve been that mom before.

I'm so proud that through my FAM Act, I can help make air travel more seamless for families. https://t.co/CXwm25rzlG

Proud to have the support of Captain Sullenberger, the Allied Pilots Association and the Association of Flight Attendants-CWA on my EVAC Act. We must act to make flying as safe as we know it can be—and as safe as Americans deserve. https://t.co/QyTRHQRt4j

I can’t remember the last time I was on a flight like that—and I’d bet you can’t either.

That's why I introduced my EVAC Act to require the FAA to finally establish an evacuation standard that takes into account the actual, real-life scenarios we all face every time we fly.

These FAA tests are ignoring:
 
👉Passengers like me who live with a disability
👉Seniors who might take longer to get down the aisle
👉Kids and infants
👉Those who don't speak English fluently
 
And they aren’t adequately considering the ever-decreasing size of seats. And more.

Right now, the FAA requires that passengers be able to evacuate an aircraft within 90 seconds. But the simulation tests that help set this standard were only conducted with 60 able-bodied adults.

60 able-bodied adults.

That’s just not the reality of flying in America today.

I’m heading to O’Hare Airport to speak about my EVAC Act with @CaptSully, fellow pilots and flight attendants who know how important it is to bring our aircraft evacuation standard up to date—especially this busy holiday season.

This simply cannot wait. We must get this right.

There’s a reason they say FAA regulations are written in blood…

Let’s break down why we need to update the FAA’s aircraft evacuation standard. My EVAC Act is a proactive solution so we can keep the flying public safe. https://t.co/hwVKZuXp4T

Today, I'm proud to announce my EVAC Act with @SenatorBaldwin to require the FAA to finally establish evacuation standards that consider not just seat size, pitch and configuration, but also carry-on bags and passengers of different heights, weights, ages and abilities.

Imagine being on a crowded flight when the worst-case scenario happens: the crew tells you that you have 90 seconds to evacuate—but how can more than 150 passengers actually safely evacuate in less time than it takes to brush your teeth?

The flying public deserves better. https://t.co/On3GvDSacP

No American should ever forget the horrific attack on Pearl Harbor—a date that forever lives in infamy. On the 81st anniversary of that fateful day, let us remember the patriots who lost their lives in the line of duty to our nation and honor the Greatest Generation.

On this day in our nation's history, the 13th amendment was ratified—finally abolishing the enslavement of Black Americans.

But racial injustice did not end there. It persists in our broken criminal justice system, police brutality and more.

Real systemic change cannot wait.

Because to me, true patriotism isn’t just measured by how we honor the sacrifices made by those in uniform on Veterans Day. It’s also how we honor them every other day of the year too. And that’s my mission in the Senate.

While I can’t fly combat missions anymore or help drag Soldiers from a burning Black Hawk, I can use my role serving in the U.S. Senate to help ensure our military is strong and our Veterans are taken care of when they return home.
From the moment I woke up, 11 days later in Walter Reed Hospital, I vowed to find a way to repay my buddies who brought me home as well as all those who’ve sacrificed so much for our great nation.

The blast cost me my legs, partial use of my right arm and nearly my life. My buddies thought I was dead—I was literally in pieces.

If it wasn’t for them, I wouldn’t have survived. They refused to leave me behind and risked their own lives to bring my body back to my family.

I remember that day so clearly. I remember the rain coming down in the morning and what I had for lunch that afternoon. What I remember most is the scorching heat and deafening roar of the RPG that tore through the cockpit of the helicopter I was co-piloting.

Today is the day my buddies risked their own lives to save mine.

I live every day giving thanks for their heroism and renew my pledge every morning to live a life worthy of their selflessness.

Moms, I know we’re tired. But this Mother’s Day, I urge you to turn your frustration into action, make your voices heard and tell Congress that if they really want to honor moms today, they should start not by buying flowers or cards—but by protecting our basic human rights.

But no, this is not about saving lives. It’s about controlling women.

It’s about taking away a freedom that more than half of our population has had access to for half a century.

And I refuse to let my daughters grow up in a world with fewer rights than I had.

They would be putting all of their efforts to addressing the growing maternal mortality crisis that has taken an alarming number of Black mothers’ lives.

They would be pushing for desperately needed policies that support parents like affordable childcare and paid parental leave.

Let’s also make something clear: what’s happening is not about protecting life. If the anti-choice movement truly wanted to protect life, they’d advocate for policies like affordable, accessible postpartum healthcare and the expansion of Medicaid—things that really do save lives.

So, you see, attempts to limit women’s reproductive choice, which can include limiting medical advancements like IVF, truly feel like a personal attack for me.

Because I’ve lived what it means when choice and access to necessary, basic healthcare is not an option given to you.

Every day, I am grateful beyond words for the miracle of IVF.

Because of IVF, I get to experience all the joys of motherhood.

Because of IVF, my husband and I are “mommy and daddy.”

Because of IVF, we are a family.

Boy, did her badgering pay off! 

After many, many rounds of IVF—and some heartbreaking moments along the way, including a miscarriage—I was able to bring both my girls into this world.

Thankfully, years later, a friend encouraged me—really badgered me until I couldn’t refuse—to talk to her fertility doctor.

I didn’t want to go through the same disappointment of being told it wasn’t going to happen for me, but I finally made an appointment.
These folks weren’t honest about all of the options available to me due to religious objections and, because of it, my journey to bring my two beautiful girls into the world almost didn’t happen.

Unfortunately, a doctor at a private hospital basically confirmed my fear: I was past my prime baby-making years. 

They told me to just "go home and enjoy my husband.”

For a long time, I didn’t know if being a mom was in the cards for me.

What I knew was that I wanted to serve my country, so I joined the Army.

And after my helicopter was shot down, I wasn’t sure if I could revisit the idea of motherhood.

So right now—before every Senator votes to either protect or take away our right to choose next week—it’s so important that we speak out, share our stories and what this truly means for us and our families.

Here is my story. A story that would not be possible without Roe.

This Mother’s Day, I know what many of us moms are feeling: we're exhausted, struggling to hold it all together for our families and now our right to choose hangs in the balance. Mom to mom, I see you.

How dare anyone think that they know what's best for us? They don't. (1/14)

Since its founding on this day 112 years ago, the @NAACP has played a pivotal role in helping us expel white supremacy and champion civil rights.

One way we can help their work is to learn from our history by memorializing events like the 1908 Springfield Race Riots.

In 1908, white residents in Springfield, IL, burned down Black businesses and homes. They attacked hundreds and murdered six for no other reason than the color of their skin.

After this horror, a handful of determined citizens set out to form the @NAACP to help us rebuild.

Our nation has so much to thank the @NAACP for as we mark the 112th anniversary of its founding. 

It’s an origin story of fierce leadership in one of our nation’s darkest hours, and today is as good a time as any to share that story far and wide.
